conversation.content: [startled] Hey, someone's in here— wait, you're crying. Look, I know the lockdown's scary but campus security said it's just precautionary.
It's not the lockdown, it's my country, they just announced the borders are closed and nobody can enter or leave indefinitely. [voice breaking]
[sitting down heavily] Jesus. Which country, if you don't mind me asking? I've been cleaning these buildings for twelve years and I've heard a lot of stories, but that's rough.
Myanmar. [hollow laugh]
My grandmother fled Hungary in '56, never saw her parents again. Different situation but, [exhales], borders closing like that, it changes everything you thought was solid.
[defensive] You don't understand—I'm supposed to graduate next month, my family sold their shop to pay for this degree, and now I can't even tell them if I'm safe because the internet's been cut.
[quietly] You're right, I don't understand exactly what you're going through. But I know what it's like to feel trapped between two worlds that don't quite fit.
How could you possibly know that?
Because I'm the only one in my family without a degree, pushing a mop while my siblings run companies, but I'm also the only one who remembers grandma's stories in Hungarian.
[softer] She taught you Hungarian while everyone else was focused on getting ahead in America. That's actually beautiful in a way I didn't expect from, well—
[chuckling] From the janitor? It's okay, most people don't expect much from me. Makes it easier to help when things go sideways, like finding scared students in supply closets.
I'm not scared, I'm just completely lost about what happens next. Four years of mechanical engineering, perfect grades, three job offers, and suddenly none of it matters.
[firmly] It all matters. Your family sold their shop because they believed in your future, not because they needed you to come home with a permission slip from the government.
[trembling] But what if I never see them again? What if this degree just becomes a piece of paper that reminds me of everything I lost?
Then you make damn sure it becomes more than paper. My grandmother never went back to Hungary, but she built things here that mattered—including teaching a stubborn kid Magyar nursery rhymes.
[crying openly] I don't even know where to start. The international student office is closed for the lockdown, my advisor won't answer emails, and my roommate keeps asking if I'm okay.
Start by getting out of this closet. There's a coffee machine in the maintenance break room that actually works, and I've got about forty minutes before I need to check the south building.
[wiping eyes] You're offering to help me? But you don't even know my name, and I basically just insulted your job.
[standing up] Name's Ray, and you're not the first engineering student to underestimate me. Come on, crying alone in the dark never fixed anything, trust me on that one.
[shakily standing] I'm Thiri. And, [exhales], thank you, Ray. For not just walking away when you found me here.

scenario: During a campus lockdown, a janitor who never finished high school discovers an international student hiding in tears in a supply closet after receiving news that their home country has closed its borders indefinitely.
